bibl.title: Lives of the Eastern Saints I
Zeʿora

event.desc: Zeʿora miraculously restored a spring that had stopped flowing

person.persName: The monk who witnessed the miracle performed by Zeʿora

personGrp.persName: The persons who gathered together to be blessed by Zeʿora

event.desc: The Huns arrived and threatened the holy men, probably in 515.
Zeʿora miraculously stopped a Hun from killing him, probably in 515.

personGrp.persName: The mighty hosts of the Huns

person.persName: The Hun barbarian who tried to kill Zeʿora

event.desc: Zeʿora's master died.
Zeʿora made a column for himself and stood on it.
From atop his column Zeʿora healed the sick by blessing water and sprinkling it on them.
Chalcedonian persecutors removed Zeʿora from his column.
Zeʿora took ten disciples and traveled to Constantinople in order to protest the treatment of the non-Chalcedonians to the emperor

personGrp.persName: The ten disciples who followed Zeʿora to the royal city

person.persName: The king who was visited by Zeʿora

event.desc: The persecutors of Zeʿora sent letters to Constantinople to explain their treatment of Zeʿora.

The emperor and a group of bishops assemble to oppose Zeʿora. Zeʿora speaks boldly in defense of his non-Chalcedonian convictions and against the persecution of non-Chalcedonians. The emperor oppossed Zeʿora but also feared him.
Zeʿora anathematized the Council of Chalcedon and inflicted the emperor with swelling and a compromised mental state.

personGrp.persName: The magistrates who witnessed the encounter between Zeʿora and Justinian

event.desc: The empress hid the emperor from all but two physicians and two chamberlains while she convinced Zeʿora to heal the emperor.

personGrp.persName: The intercessors who were sent to fetch Zeʿora

event.desc: Zeʿora restored the emperor to health and the emperor relented from pusuing strict persecution of non-Chalcedonians.
Zeʿora's fame grew, extending as far as the city of Rome and enabling him to have great influence among the emperor and the senators. He used this influence to care for the poor.
Pope Agepetus, who was about to blaspheme by declaring that Mary should not be commemorated in the church, urged the emperor to expel Zeʿora.

occupation.note: Agapetus was the Patriarch of Rome

personGrp.persName: The followers of Paul of Samosata

event.desc: Papal and imperial representatives crossed the Golden Horn to Sycae and confronted Zeʿora, demanding he obey the emperor. Zeʿora refused and they attempted to forcibly bring him into the city but heavy winds prevented their crossing the Golden Horn.
Pope Agepetus dies suddenly on the day predicted by Zeʿora and Zeʿora's opponents accuse him of using magic against the Pope.

personGrp.persName: The heretics in churches and monasteries who complained against Zeʿora

event.desc: Zeʿora engaged in affective prayer.
Zeʿora performed many acts of charity for the poor
Heretics petitioned the king and queen to have Zeʿora removed from the city
Zeʿora left the city to dwell in the same city as Theodosius.
Zeʿora died, leaving behind his disciple Hananya.
